official_title: Phase III Trial of Single Fraction Stereotactic Radiosurgery (SRS) Versus Fractionated SRS (FSRS) for Intact Brain Metastases
brief_title: Testing Longer Duration Radiation Therapy Versus the Usual Radiation Therapy in Patients With Cancer That Has Spread to the Brain
cancer_type_display: A study comparing fractionated stereotactic radiosurgery (FSRS) to single-fraction stereotactic radiosurgery (SRS) for patients whose cancer has spread to the brain from primary sites such as lung, breast, melanoma, or kidney.
cancer_tags: Anatomic Stage IV Breast Cancer AJCC v8
Metastatic Malignant Neoplasm in the Brain
Stage IV Lung Cancer AJCC v8
Stage IV Renal Cell Cancer AJCC v8
prior_treatments_excluded: Prior radiotherapy to the brain (partial or whole brain irradiation, SRS, FSRS, or prophylactic cranial irradiation [PCI])

locations.facility: University of Arizona Cancer Center-North Campus

key_inclusion_summary: Pathologically proven diagnosis of a solid tumor malignancy (NSCLC, melanoma, breast, renal cell, or GI cancer).
Must have 1 to 8 total intact brain metastases.
At least one lesion must have a maximum diameter of ≥ 1.0 cm and ≤ 3.0 cm.
key_exclusion_summary: Metastases located in the brainstem or less than 5 mm from the optic nerves or chiasm.
